results.title: Heat and dust
results.creator_credit: James Ivory, Ismail Merchant and Merchant Ivory Productions
results.brief_description: A young English woman journeys to India to explore the mysterious and scandalous past of her Great-aunt sixty years ago. Both succumb to the beauty of the land and its people and become pregnant. Nevertheless, they remain outsiders in a land they can never fully comprehend. Stars Julie Christie, Greta Scacchi and Madhur Jaffrey.

results.title: Heat = Andy Warhol presents Heat
results.creator_credit: Paul Morrissey, Andy Warhol and Score Movies
results.brief_description: Largely interpreted as a send-up of “Sunset Boulevard”, this is the story of Joe (Joe Dallesandro) a handsome, ambitious would-be actor who, whilst staying in a shoddy LA Motel, sleeps with an array of staff and customers, anyone in fact who he believes will further his career. Joe displays all the hallmarks of a jaded hustler - a man beyond enjoyment of sex, but one for whom sex is the main currency. The final instalment of the “Flesh/Trash/Heat” trilogy, between Paul Morrissey, Joe Dallesandro and Andy Warhol, this is the most linear of their work and the least experimental. It contains some wonderfully satirical humour whilst remaining focused (as “Heat” and “Trash” did also) on Dallesandro’s physical beauty. Cast also includes Sylvia Miles, Ray Vestal, Andrea Feldman and Pat Ast.

results.title: Heat
results.creator_credit: Michael Mann, Art Linson, Regency Entertainment (USA) and Monarchy Enterprises B. V.
results.brief_description: Neil McCauley (Robert De Niro) is a professional. He is meticulous and cautious. He also is a professional robber. After a successful heist, LA cop Vincent Hanna (Al Pacino) is on McCauley’s trail and out to stop him. The two are soon caught in an epic battle and yet they recognise that they are actually essentialy the same. Michael Mann’s “Heat” is a rivetting action film which also attempts to examine in some depth the lives of the film’s characters, in particular Vincent and Neil as well as the other members of his team. By casting dynamic actors like De Niro and Pacino in the lead roles, as well as Val Kilmer and John Voight in supporting roles, the focus on character remains engaging in the midst of the explosive violence of the action sequences which drive the film along.

results.title: Hearts of the world
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith, War Office Committee and D W Griffith Productions
results.brief_description: After producing BIRTH OF A NATION and INTOLERANCE Griffith was commissioned by the American government to produce a propaganda film for the Allies in World War 1. Although not in the same class as his two masterpieces, HEARTS OF THE WORLD is nevertheless well in the Griffith tradition of striking sets, visual flair and spectacular battle scenes. A group of youngsters grow up and love in a peaceful French village. But war intrudes and peace is shattered. The German army invades and occupies village, bringing both destruction and torture. The young people of the village resist, some successfully, others tragically, until French troops retake the town. Stars Lillian Gish, Robert Harron, Dorothy Gish, Adolphe Lestina and Josephine Crowell. Noel Coward and Erich von Stroheim play small parts.

results.title: Hearts of darkness: a filmmaker's apocalypse
results.creator_credit: Eleanor Coppola, George Hickenlooper, Fax Bahr, Les Mayfield, George Zaloom and ZM Productions
results.brief_description: The making of “Apocalypse now” was almost the breaking of famed director Francis Ford Coppola. For three years Coppola drove and dragged his actors, including Robert Duvall, Martin Sheen, Marlon Brando, and his crew through torturous conditions to complete his epic portrayal of the Vietnam War. Recreating the savagery of war left its mark - Sheen overcame a heart attack to finish the film and Coppola privately questioned his sanity. This riveting, funny and at times shocking film charts the progress of Coppola’s dream, which he personally funded to completion. It is brutally honest and includes improvisation, often drug-induced, which made it to the big screen as “brilliant performances”. Features exclusively restored footage previously deleted from “Apocalypse now”, “Hearts of darkness” is a tragedy, comedy and disaster rolled into one.

results.title: Hearts in Atlantis
results.creator_credit: Scott Hicks, Kerry Heysen, Village Roadshow Pictures, NPV Entertainment and Castle Rock Entertainment
results.brief_description: A nostalgic film set in small town America of the 1960s about maturation and the loss of innocence. Bobby is an eleven-year-old boy feeling the stigma of being from a financially strapped one-parent family. One summer a mysterious boarder Ted Brautigan (Anthony Hopkins) comes to live in the upstairs part of the house and wins over Bobby, if not his suspicious mother, Liz. It is gradually revealed that Ted has psychic powers and sinister men in dark suits are pursuing him. Bobby, in need of a father figure, is drawn into Ted’s confidence, working for him, and absorbing Ted’s wisdom. Ted assists Bobby with difficult life matters - his first kiss, trust in others, and lessons in disappointment. Structured as a flashback, “Hearts in Atlantis” has a tone not unlike a darkly themed episode of “The Wonder years.” Hicks peppers a pedestrian screenplay, laden with symbolic diatribes, with 60s hits, an expressive score, and an eye for period detail. Hope Davis puts in an understated performance as Liz - a woman who struggles with her financial situation, whilst fending off her lecherous boss. Directed by Scott Hicks (Shine, Snow falling on cedars).

results.title: Hearts and Minds
results.brief_description: Many times during his presidency, Lyndon B. Johnson said that ultimate victory in the Vietnam War depended upon the U.S. military winning the “hearts and minds” of the Vietnamese people. Filmmaker Peter Davis uses Johnson’s phrase in an ironic context in this anti-war documentary.

constellations_other.name: Dial M for Media
constellations_other.description: Explores the nature of media use in high-profile cases as well as the ability of media to sway public minds.

results.description: Many times during his presidency, Lyndon B. Johnson said that ultimate victory in the Vietnam War depended upon the U.S. military winning the “hearts and minds” of the Vietnamese people. Filmmaker Peter Davis uses Johnson’s phrase in an ironic context in this anti-war documentary, filmed and released while the Vietnam War was still under way, juxtaposing interviews with military figures like U.S. Army Chief of Staff William C. Westmoreland with shocking scenes of violence and brutality.

results.title: Hearts and minds
results.brief_description: The evolution of civilization throughout the world is contrasted with the lack of development, the exploitation, and agony of Vietnam, through the ages. Problems of power, human rights, domestic politics, national prestige, and development of economy are so involved with fallible political processes; “Peace”, “Ceasefire”, “Negotiation”, become meaningless re-iterations. Petty’s first film comprising footage that he shot on a trip to Vietnam combined with animation of some of his newspape cartoons. Accompanied with music by George Dreyfus, the narrative builds to a strong anti-war statement.
